Act1Scene2.speaker: Duncan
Act1Scene2.text: What bloody man is that? He can report, As seemeth by his plight, of the revolt The newest state.
Act1Scene2.translation: Who is this bleeding soldier? He looks as if he can tell us the latest news of the battle.

Act1Scene2.speaker: Malcolm
Act1Scene2.text: This is the sergeant Who  fought ’Gainst my captivity.—Hail, brave friend! Say to the King the knowledge of the broil As thou didst leave it.

Act1Scene2.speaker: Captain
Act1Scene2.text: Doubtful it stood, As two spent swimmers that do cling together And choke their art. The merciless Macdonwald from the Western Isles Of kerns and gallowglasses is supplied. But all’s too weak; for brave Macbeth with his brandished steel, carved out his passage till he faced the slave which he unseamed him from the nave to th’ chops, and fixed his head upon our battlements
Act1Scene2.translation: The battle was uncertain, like two tired swimmers clinging to each other. Macdonwald, supplied by the Western Isles, seemed unstoppable. But brave Macbeth carved through the enemy until he killed Macdonwald and displayed his head on our battlements.

Act1Scene2.speaker: Captain
Act1Scene2.text: No sooner justice had, with valor armed, compelled these skipping kerns to trust their heels, but the Norweyan lord, surveying vantage, with furbished arms and new supplies of men, began a fresh assault.
Act1Scene2.translation: Just as we thought the battle was over, the Norwegian king launched a fresh assault

Act1Scene2.speaker: Duncan
Act1Scene2.text: Dismayed not this our captains, Macbeth and Banquo?

Act1Scene2.speaker: Captain
Act1Scene2.text: Yes, they doubly redoubled strokes upon the foe. except they meant to bathe in reeking wounds or memorize another Golgotha, I cannot tell—but I am faint. My gashes cry for help

Act1Scene2.speaker: Duncan
Act1Scene2.text: So well thy words become thee as thy wounds: They smack of honor both.—Go, get him surgeons. Who comes here?
Act1Scene2.translation: Their courage is remarkable. Now get this captain treated

Act1Scene2.speaker: Ross
Act1Scene2.text: From Fife, great king,Norway himself, with terrible numbers, assisted by that most disloyal traitor, The Thane of Cawdor, began a dismal conflict, till that Bellona’s bridegroom, lapped in proof, confronted him Curbing his lavish spirit. And to conclude, the victory fell on us
Act1Scene2.translation: Norway attacked with the traitorous Thane of Cawdor. But Macbeth confronted him and secured our victory

Act1Scene2.speaker: Duncan
Act1Scene2.text: No more that Thane of Cawdor shall deceive our bosom interest. Go, pronounce his present death, and with his former title greet Macbeth.

Act1Scene2.speaker: Duncan
Act1Scene2.text: What he hath lost, noble Macbeth hath won
